Vanderbilt University is one of those colleges that is quite conservative overall.
 It has many student newspapers and none of them I would call liberal. There is a satirical paper, but just doing satire doesn't make it liberal.
 
 But there is a conservative commentary paper, they even have a website:
 
 http://www.vutorch.org/blog/
 
 The main problem I have with this paper is the little section "Pearls of Wisdom" where they list a few quotes. The quotes can be pretty stupid.
 
 One is:
 "A free lunch is only found in mousetraps." - John Capozzi
 
 Hmm, if you have to pay the ultimate price for your lunch, how free is it?
 
 But another was quite good and it really shows you how UNconservative the current trend of "conservatism" is:
 
 "It is amazing how many people seem to think that the government exists to turn their prejudices into law." - Thomas Sowell
 
 These were the other two, I thought they were quite good:
 
 "Imposing controls to stop a price increase is like trying to cure a fever by pushing down the mercury in a thermometer." - Murray Rothard
 (well, the anaolgy is a tad off since impsing artificial controls on prices would stop the price increase - it just wouldn't solve the problem that led to it.)
 
 "I am certain that nothing has done so much to destroy the judicial safeguards of individual freedom as the striving after this mirage of social justice." - Frederich von Hayek
 
 
 Anyway, are there any other people out there that either work at or near, or attend a university that is predominantly conservative (in atmosphere and the minds of the student body)?

They are one of only two colleges in the nation that refuse to take any Federal funding so that Washington can't impose any control over it. Their newspaper is called Imprimis. Here's a link to the school. Check it out.
 http://www.hillsdale.edu/

 Have you looked at any of the stats? Nearly every college in the country is made up of a majority of teachers who are Liberal. I saw on TV the other day some interesting facts on this subject. I think at the Univ. of Colorado 90% of the teachers were liberal and 10% conservative. This was nearly the same for Stanford, Harvard, Yale, Princeton, and many other schools.
 
 Why are such an overwhelming majority of professors liberal? Certainly the majority of the country isn't liberal.

 There's some truth to that. Most Conservatives with advanced degrees that I know have technical degrees and go into industry where the "real" money is and not into teaching. This leaves the Liberals to feast on young impressionable minds.
 Another interesting stat is that more Republicans have college degrees than Democrats. The reason that more don't have advanced degrees is the same reason that they aren't staying around and becoming professors. They're true capitalists; they get a job. :)

 I'm not disagreeing with you on any points, except that you aren't being a capitalist when you get a job working for someone else that pays you a wage or salary.
 
 The capitalist is the guy risking his capital to pay your wage.
 
 Once upon a time in this country, wage labor was seen as a hair above slavery (and at the time it was). Only by having a craft or owning a business or a farm were you seen as totally free and independent. Factory work was seen as a sort of socialism (we're talking late eighteenth, early nineteenth century here.) 
 
 Oh, and being a college professor is quite a real job, btw. 
 Also, the one's I know make some "real" money, as you put it (comparable to industry).

 Well, ok, maybe profs don't spend as many hours in the air, but they are always going to conferences. I'd say an average chemistry prof goes to about 5 of them a year (usually around the country, but sometimes overseas). I'm sure this doesn't compare to these VPs schedules, or their salaries. It is a special prof that makes over a million (we have one here in our dept.) it usually depends on how much the school wants you, how much money they have, is there an endowed chair that they have to offer, and so on. I remember Vanderbilt passed on this one guy because he wanted a private elevator going straight to his office :) (and cuz he wanted too much money. I think somebody picked him up though.
 
 Anywho, on average people in industry do make more, and there are more of them.

By definition, an institute of learning must be "liberal." Without being open to new or contradictory ideas, the institution becomes useless to it's students. The problem seems to be that we have accepted the misuse of the "liberal" label by "conservative" politicians and media.
 Maybe some education is in order...

 "Liberal" in its purest form shares more with Conservativism than it does modern liberalism. A liberal in our forefather's time was someone like Jefferson or Madison who stressed individualism over collectivism. Modern liberals are the epitome of collectivism. They want socialist programs such as SS, Medicare, Medicaid, Federal Housing, etc., and are all for forcing the "haves" to support the "have-nots". This isn't the philosophy of jefferson and Madison. This is the philosophy of Karl Marx. emoticon_mad

"Liberal" in its purest form shares more with Conservativism than it does modern liberalism. :

 
 While I'll agree that Liberalism has lost much of it's original meaning, and the spirit of open-mindedness that it should represent is hard to find in groups classified as "liberal" today, I will take exception to the idea that Liberal has any relation to Conservatism. This is simply because I am a liberal (in the proper meaning of the term).
 Conservatism, in it's most basic form means simply to maintain the status quo. This is the antithesis of Liberalism (to explore new ideas).
 America is a liberal country, founded on liberal ideals by liberals. There were conservatives back in the days of the founding of America; they were called Tories. Had the conservative viewpoint won out, we would all still be subjects of the queen.

The latter is nothing more than another flavor of modern liberalism, ie., socialism.
